entry.title: Wind Advisory issued April 7 at 1:52AM CDT until April 7 at 3:00PM CDT by NWS Quad Cities IA IL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Southeast winds 25 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph expected.
* WHERE...Portions of north central, northwest, and west central Illinois and east central, northeast, and southeast Iowa.
* WHEN...From 6 AM this morning to 3 PM CDT this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 7 at 1:48AM CDT by NWS Des Moines IA
entry.summary:
Stronger east to southeast winds will continue to impact the region from time to this early this Sunday morning through mid morning. Winds of 25 to 30 mph at times with gusts nearing 45 mph will impact travel; especially for higher profile vehicles and trailers traveling on north south roads and to some extent on east west roads as well.
Please use caution if stronger winds are encountered and slow travel to maintain vehicle stability. The winds will gradually lessen through the morning with breezy conditions for much of the rest of the day.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 7 at 12:39AM MDT until April 7 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
...Very Dangerous Fire Weather Conditions Today...
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 001 Cheyenne, 013 Sherman, 027 Wallace, 041 Greeley, 252 Yuma, 253 Kit Carson and 254 Cheyenne.
* WINDS...West to Northwest at 30 to 50 mph with gusts ranging from 55 to 75 mph, strongest along and north of Interstate 70 during the late morning and early afternoon.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Extreme and unpredictable fire behavior. Any fires that start are likely to grow and rapidly spread out of control.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yuma; Kit Carson County; Cheyenne; Cheyenne; Sherman; Wallace; Greeley

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued April 7 at 12:30AM MDT until April 7 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
* WHAT...West to Northwest winds at 35 to 55 mph with gusts up to 75 mph.
* WHERE...Portions of east central and northeast Colorado, northwest and west central Kansas, and southwest Nebraska.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM MDT /7 PM CDT/ this evening.
* IMPACTS...Very dangerous travel and fire weather conditions. Wind of this magnitude may down trees and power lines. Property damage and power outages are likely.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...West to northwest winds will strengthen and extend southward to the Interstate 70 corridor early this morning. The strongest winds are anticipated to occur between sunrise and noon, when hurricane force wind gusts are possible. Although winds will gradually decrease in intensity this afternoon, strong winds are likely to persist until sunset.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yuma County; Kit Carson County; Cheyenne; Rawlins; Decatur; Norton; Sherman; Thomas; Sheridan; Graham; Wallace; Logan; Gove; Dundy; Hitchcock; Red Willow

cap:parameter.value: HIGH WIND WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM MDT /7 PM CDT/ THIS EVENING

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 6 at 11:59PM MDT until April 7 at 6:00AM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches. Winds gusting as high as 50 mph.
* WHERE...Flat Tops.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM MDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Patchy blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility, especially on ridge tops. The cold wind chills as low as 15 below zero could result in hypothermia if precautions are not taken. A detailed map of the snowfall can be found at: www.weather.gov/gjt/winter.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Flat Tops

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 6 at 11:58PM MDT until April 8 at 6:00AM MDT by NWS Cheyenne WY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 12 inches. Some locations in far northern portions of Goshen County may exceed 12 inches. Winds gusting as high as 70 mph.
* WHERE...Goshen County, primarily north of Highway 26. The heaviest snowfall accumulations will be in the far northern portion of Goshen County. Much lower snowfall accumulations are expected south of Highway 26.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM MDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Widespread blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Very strong winds could cause extensive tree damage.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...There is a possibility areas in the winter storm warning could see little to no snowfall due to a very sharp gradient in snowfall accumulations.

* WHERE...East Platte County, primarily north of Highway 26 and east of Interstate 25. Areas south of Highway 26 may see little to no snowfall accumulation.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM MDT Monday.

entry.title: Blizzard Warning issued April 6 at 11:58PM MDT until April 8 at 6:00AM MDT by NWS Cheyenne WY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blizzard conditions expected. Heavy wet snow expected. A rain and snow mix may transition to rain on Sunday afternoon before changing back to snow showers Sunday evening. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches south of the North Platte River Valley anticipated in the highest elevations. Winds gusting as high as 70 mph.
* WHERE...Scotts Bluff County and Banner County. Primarily south of the North Platte River Valley.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM MDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Widespread blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Very strong winds could cause extensive tree damage.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The Blizzard Warning replaces the current High Wind Warning in effect for the central and southern portions of the Nebraska Panhandle.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Scotts Bluff; Banner; Morrill; Kimball; Cheyenne

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued April 7 at 2:57PM ChST until April 10 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 10 to 12 ft and minor coastal flooding.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Majuro.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, from 3 PM Monday to 3 PM ChST Wednesday. For the Coastal Flood Statement, through Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Splashing waves along seawall and coastal roads, in addition to ponding in waterfront properties is possible, especially during high tide due to minor coastal inundation induced by this King Tide cycle. Surf is expected to continue to increase the next few days, with surf expected to reach 12 feet Monday night. Shores with higher exposure to localized wind waves and swells may see slightly higher pulses of inundation through Wednesday afternoon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Majuro

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 7 at 12:48AM EDT until April 8 at 12:00PM EDT by NWS Northern Indiana
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana... Ohio...
Tippecanoe River above Winamac affecting Pulaski, White and Carroll Counties.
Tippecanoe River near Ora affecting Fulton IN, Kosciusko, Starke, Pulaski and Marshall Counties.
Wabash River near Linn Grove affecting Wells and Adams Counties.
Saint Joseph River Ohio near Newville affecting De Kalb, Allen IN and Defiance Counties.
Saint Marys River near Decatur affecting Allen IN, Adams and Van Wert Counties.
Tiffin River at Stryker affecting Fulton OH, Defiance and Williams Counties.
For the Tippecanoe River...including Ora, Winamac, Norway Dam... Minor flooding is forecast. For the Wabash River...including Linn Grove, Bluffton IN, Wabash, Logansport...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Saint Joseph River Ohio...including Montpelier, Newville, St. Joe River Ft. Wayne...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Saint Marys River...including Decatur, St. Mary's River near Fort Wayne...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Tiffin River...including Stryker...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. This approaches the flood of record.
* WHERE...Wabash River near Linn Grove.
* WHEN...Until early tomorrow afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, The flooding of county roads begin.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:45 PM EDT Saturday the stage was 11.7 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:45 PM EDT Saturday was 13.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this afternoon and continue falling to 8.2 feet Thursday evening. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Adams, IN; Wells, IN

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY TOMORROW AFTERNOON

entry.summary:

* WHERE...In Montana, Southern Big Horn. In Wyoming, Sheridan Foothills.
* WHEN...Until noon MDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Lower elevations, including most populated locations, will see lighter snow accumulations and minimal travel difficulties. The impactful snow accumulations will be confined to the higher hilltops, where 10 to 18 inches of heavy wet snow is expected, and locally heavier accumulations are possible. This includes Aberdeen Hill, the Wolf Mountains, and the higher terrain southeast of Sheridan.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The heavy wet snow and poor visibility will make rural travel difficult. The combination of gusty winds and wet snow may bring down tree limbs and power lines, resulting in power outages. Severe travel conditions will impact portions of I-90 over the higher terrain.

* WHERE...In Montana, Pryor/Northern Bighorn Mountains. In Wyoming, Northeast Bighorn Mountains.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM MDT Monday.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued April 6 at 7:51PM MDT until April 7 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY MORNING THROUGH SUNDAY EVENING FOR ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Winds will not be as strong on Sunday, but strong enough when combined with persistent very low relative humidity for another round of critical fire weather conditions across eastern New Mexico.
* AREA AND TIMING...This includes all of eastern New Mexico (Zones 104, 123, 125, and 126) this afternoon through this evening and again Sunday morning through Sunday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS... Today, west 30 to 45 mph with gusts to 65 mph. On Sunday, west 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 10 and 15 percent today and between 6 and 12 percent on Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued April 6 at 3:55PM EDT until April 7 at 1:00PM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:

* WHERE...Eastern Essex MA, Suffolk MA, Eastern Norfolk MA, Eastern Plymouth MA, Barnstable MA, Dukes MA and Nantucket MA Counties.
* WHEN...From 9 AM to 1 PM EDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Shallow pockets of flooding less than one foot deep affects the lowest lying areas along the coast, including Morrissey Boulevard in Boston. Most roads remain passable. Flooding up to one foot deep affects coastal roads on the North Shore from Salem to Gloucester and Newburyport. Rough surf will cause flooding on some coastal roads around the time of high tide due to splashover. Roads remain passable. Low lying areas and roads near Nantucket Harbor, including Easy Street, may experience pockets of shallow flooding less than one foot deep.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued April 6 at 3:39PM EDT until April 8 at 12:00AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one foot of inundation above ground level expected in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...Kent, Inland Sussex and Delaware Beaches.
* WHEN...From 6 PM Sunday to midnight EDT Sunday night.
* IMPACTS...At this level, flooding begins on the most vulnerable roads in coastal and bayside communities, and along inland tidal waterways. Some partial or full road closures are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Additional rounds of minor tidal flooding are likely with the high tide cycles on Monday, especially the evening one.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 6 at 12:39PM MDT by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Idaho...
Portneuf River at Pocatello affecting Bannock County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Portneuf River at Pocatello.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.2 feet, Flooding of low lying agricultural land and pasture will occur in the Inkom and Blackrock area. Lowland flooding is likely along sections of the river between Portneuf Gap and the Cheyenne Avenue Bridge in Pocatello.
At 8.5 feet, Sections of Sacajawea Park will be under water and the trail is usually closed at this level. Marsh Creek near Inkom may also be over its banks.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:00 PM MDT Saturday the stage was 9.1 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 12:00 PM MDT Saturday was 9.1 feet. - Forecast...The river has likely crested this afternoon and water levels are expected to drop below flood stage sometime Sunday afternoon. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.3 feet on 04/27/2019. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bannock, ID

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 6 at 12:18PM MDT until April 7 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
* Affected Area...Fire Weather Zones 238 and 239.
* Timing...From noon today through 6 PM Sunday.
* Winds...Northwest increasing to 35 to 55 mph with gusts between 70 and 90 mph by tonight. Winds slowly decrease Sunday.
* Relative Humidity...As low as 18 percent.
* Impacts...Conditions will be favorable for rapid fire spread. Avoid outdoor burning and any activity that may produce a spark and start a wildfire.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Larimer County Below 6000 Feet/Northwest Weld County; Boulder And Jefferson Counties Below 6000 Feet/West Broomfield County

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 7 at 2:30AM ChST until April 7 at 6:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
...GUSTY WINDS AND DRY VEGETATION WILL MAINTAIN A HIGH FIRE THREAT...
* WIND...East wind 10 to 20 mph with gusts to 25 mph. Winds could be slightly higher in the higher terrain.
* HUMIDITY...50 to 60 percent, especially from late morning through sunset.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended. Conditions will ease during the nighttime hours.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 6 at 10:15AM MDT until April 10 at 11:59AM MDT by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Oregon...
Owyhee River Below Owyhee Dam affecting Malheur County.
For the Owyhee River...including Owyhee Dam, Owyhee Dam...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Owyhee River below Owyhee Dam.
* WHEN...Until late Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 6,000.0 cfs, Significant field flooding will occur near the river from the mouth of the canyon to the confluence with the Snake River. Water will begin to flow across Overstreet Road near the bridge crossing.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 AM MDT Saturday /8:30 AM PDT Saturday/ the flow was 7,667.0 cfs. - Bankfull is 1,000 cfs. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise below flood stage early Wednesday morning and continue falling to 8,779.9 cfs this afternoon. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood flow is 3,000.0 cfs. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9,220.0 cfs on 02/23/1982. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Malheur, OR
